title: A journal of a residence ... in London; including excursions through various parts of England; and a short tour in France and Scotland; in the years 1823 and 1824
author: Wheaton, Nathaniel Sheldon.
snippet: Crossing the North Loch, the spectator findshimself in Prince's street, a noble terrace running from eastto west along the margin ofthe Loch, above which it is elevated fifty or sixty feet. To the eastward, the Loch makes aturn to the north at the soot of Calton Hill, where it is crossed by Prince's Street, terminating in Regent Road, whichwinds around the southern base ofthe hill. Regent Bridge,extending across the Loch, is altogether a magnificent work.

title: The Red Room
author: Le Queux, William
snippet: Ten minutes later I was with the German hairdresser on a tram-car, goingup Regent Road, towards Abbey Hill. On turning into the London Road atthe station, we descended, and, crossing the main thoroughfare, enteredone of the narrow, ill-lit turnings on the left, the name of which I wasunable to see.

title: From the Thames to the Trosachs.
author: Thompson, E. H.
snippet: The temple-shaped monument of Robert Burns is on the south side of Regent Road, which leads from Holyrood to Princes Street.
